properties.media:imagetext:
Page 3
Letter No. B-33-37
Morgan
free
of interference by Japanese aircraft
especially with proper radio com-
munications and reports of raiding aircraft from the lower Yangtsze.
From
Ichang eastward the operation as indicated in our cable 143 would be with
the two Commodores and one Dolphin.
This equipment would be flown by Chinese
pilots.
We have four pilots who are capable of flying this equipment safely.
They would operate from Ichang to Hankow and on down river as far as they
could safely go.
It would be our intention to paint these airplanes green
and fly low.
The Japanese might not agree to permit these planes to fly un-
challenged but I am inclined to think with proper notice they would be re-
luctant to shoot them down.
This theory would
seem to have
some
merit in
view of the fact that Eurasia has been operating regularly into Hankow and
has recently increased its schedule to a daily operation.
I am not sure
that
a Japanese pilot would respect a Eurasia plan if he harpened to
come across
it in the air and could catch it but it would appear that there has been at
least no attempt on the part of the Japanese
to interfere with this service
as it would be a very simple
matter for
the Japanese to fly a pursuit ship
to a high altitude in the neighborhood of Hongkong and wait for the Eurgsie
plane to leave Hongkong on its daily schedule and
then catch the Eurasia
plane over Chinese territory.
one the Ears plane arrive and ento publised soned me
this would be a very simple matter
The other route
proposed to be flown would be from Chungking
to swellin to Hongkong and the Managing Director claims that this route
has been approved by
the Ministry of Communications.
It would be a DC-2
operation and
the only hazzard in my opinion would be that now run by
Burasia in its operations round about Hongkong.
The merit in the
plan as outlined in my hastily written per-
sonal letter to you dispatched by the last flight
and the radio 143,
is
that a method is provided by which we can protect PAA's investment which
otherwise may be
a total loss except for such claims as we might have against
an unfriendly Chinese Government after peace is restored.
On the other hand
if we can find any basis of cooperation which does not involve too much risk
woüld it not be better to reassociate ourselves with the operations of CNAC
and
thereby render a service of
great value to
the Chinese Government and one
which would tend to assure the carrying out of any agreement which we may now
make.
When the war is over there will still be a lot of China left and in
a11
probability
the Yangtze River and everything south will
territory•
still be Chinese
Our Peking line as you know was never a great money maker.
Yangtze River division was the real backbone of the Company
Coastal
Route gave promise
of being nearly as profitable.
In fact the Coastal Route
passenger and mail
revenue at the
time we discontinued operations was greater
on a three times a week schedule than the Peking Division had ever been on a
daily schedule.
Therefore we can probably
assume that following hostilities
the best part of CNAC's territory will still be available for operation.
the peace when it comes is a Japanese peace
all foreign advisers
forced out and we
are forced out then in that evert we
will at least have
a valid claim ageinst the Japanese for the value of our investment in China.
